name: Scientific and Academic Writing Assistance
examples:
JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN CHEMICAL SOCIETY期刊缩写 JOURNAL OF THE CHEMICAL SOCIETY-DALTON TRANSACTIONS期刊缩写 MATTER期刊缩写 NANO ENERGY NANO-MICRO LETTERS NANOSCALE NATURE NATURE COMMUNICATIONS NATURE ENERGY NATURE PHOTONICS SCIENTIFIC REPORTS 从学术论文角度，给这段话降重：
在持续光、热、氧等外界环境下，具有优异光电性能和良好稳定性的传输材料对钙钛矿吸收层的稳定性至关重要。这些材料可以屏蔽水、氧等外界因素对钙钛矿的侵蚀，抑制钙钛矿材料的分解，并有效避免离子迁移通道的形成。为了提高器件的稳定性和光电转换效率（PCE），选择和优化电荷传输材料，尤其是空穴传输材料（HTMs），至关重要。一般来说，HTMs的带隙较大，价带的能级位置相对于钙钛矿更浅。此外，空穴迁移率、导电性和易于成膜等因素也是选择HTMs时需要考虑的关键因素。
按照化学性质，常见的HTMs主要可以分成无机类、聚合物类和小分子类。

Find 6 keywords to describe a scientific article with the following abstract: "In light of the growing interest in sustainable materials within the marine industry, this article focuses on flax fiber reinforced composites as a promising alternative to synthetic fibers com-posites for boat building. The literature on this subject has expanded significantly, encompassing extensive characterization of elementary material properties and investigations into sources of variability, and applications from experimental proofs of concept to commercial releases and announcements have multiplied. This review aims to provide a concise yet comprehensive overview of the properties of flax fiber reinforced composites, synthesizing existing knowledge and highlighting key findings as well as exposing the specific behaviors of the material. Furthermore, the article presents application-oriented tests, designed to corroborate existing results and extend the understanding of these composites in marine applications. These tests include mechanical property evaluations, such as tensile, compressive and shear properties, as well as tests more closely aligned to practical applications in the marine industry. The confirmation of and contribution to these properties aims to consolidate critical data for numerical analysis, and thus to engineering design, bridging a gap between fundamental research and practical applications.".

به صورت پاراگرافی باشد متن زیر را ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک کن هم خلاصه کن و فقط هدفشون رو بگو و روش کار رو بیان کن و نتایج را نیز بگو :Abstract
A predictive understanding of interactions between vegetation and climate has been a grand challenge in terrestrial ecology for over 200 years. Developed in recent decades, continental-scale monitoring of climate and forest dynamics enables quantitative examination of vegetation–climate relationships through a data-driven paradigm. Here, we apply a data-intensive approach to investigate forest–climate interactions across the conterminous USA. We apply multivariate statistical methods (stepwise regression, principal component analysis) including machine learning to infer significant climatic drivers of standing forest basal area. We focus our analysis on the ecoregional scale. For most ecoregions analyzed, both stepwise regression and random forests indicate that factors related to precipitation are the most significant predictors of forest basal area. In almost half of US ecoregions, precipitation of the coldest quarter is the single most important driver of basal area. The demonstrated data-driven approach may be used to inform forest-climate envelope modeling and the forecasting of large-scale forest dynamics under climate change scenarios. These results have important implications for climate, biodiversity, industrial forestry, and indigenous communities in a changing world.

请翻译：“Quercus oxyphylla is an evergreen oak endemic to China that is important for maintaining the ecological stability of subtropical regions” Please revise the abstract of article"Broad temperature niche drives adaptation to future climate change for an endemic evergreen oak across Chinese subtropics":"Understanding the relationship between climate change and the geographical distribution of species is a fundamental requirement for biodiversity conservation and resource management strategies. Quercus oxyphylla is an evergreen oak endemic to China that is important for maintaining the ecological stability of subtropical regions. Meanwhile, as a precious hardwood tree, it possesses high economic value attributed to its dark and high-density heartwood, but the existing resources are close to endangered. However, information on its distribution pattern, dominant climatic factors, and potential influences of climate change on suitable areas remains limited. In this study, based on 63 occurrence records and bioclimatic predictors from current and future scenarios, we predicted changes in prospected suitable areas for Q. oxyphylla in China using the maximum entropy (MaxEnt) model under different climate scenarios. The results showed that (1) Q. oxyphylla potentially distributes in the east-west mountains (Qinling Mountains, Nanling Mountains, and Wuyi Mountains) on the southern (24.5 °N) and northern (33.9 °N) boundaries of subtropical China, which exhibited a disjunctive geographical distribution pattern of two climatic boundaries and three distribution centers. (2) The temperature-related variables were the principal determinants of the distribution pattern, including the mean diurnal range (Bio2), annual temperature range (Bio7), and isothermality (Bio3). The large difference in water and temperature conditions suggests that the habitat of Q. oxyphylla has large climatic variability and strong physiological tolerance to climate change. (3) Under future climate change scenarios, suitable projected areas will expand continuously towards subtropical China, indicating that Q. oxyphylla may adapt to future climate change due to its higher plasticity for temperature predictors and strong drought tolerance. These results can guide the development and implementation of strategies to address climate change and conserve biodiversity.
Keywords: Quercus oxyphylla; Climate change adaptation; MaxEnt modeling; Climatic niche; Species distribution model (SDM); Climatic suitability"

In 2022, the highest growth of DRI production has been observed in Qatar and India, 1.62 (105%) and 43.55 (11.4%) million tons, respectively. Compared to 2021, the production of DRI in the Islamic Republic of Iran has increased by 1.05 million tons. A slight increase in production can be seen in Argentina compared to the previous year (1.51 million tons). In Saudi Arabia, an increase in the production of DRI by 350 thousand tons has been reported. The MENA region has obtained 45.9% of the world's DRI by producing 58.46 million tons of DRI. In the previous year, Russia produced 7.66 million tons of DRI. With two key points of the world, in other words, in India and Iran, there is a large increase in production. The amount of DRI production in India has increased to 43.55 million tons, while in 2010, the amount of DRI production in this country was 23.4 million tons. 50% of India's DRI n production is used in induction furnaces. The share of Arab countries in the production of DRI in the world is 20%. ArcelorMittal chose ENERGIRON DRI technology for its Dofasco steel mill in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada. Tenova and Danieli will design and supply a 2.0 Mt/y. During the previous year, the share of DRI production processes based on gas and coal was 70.1% and 29.9%, respectively. The cumulative production of DRI by different methods from 1970 to now (2022) is estimated to be more than 20128.66 million tons. It is expected that by 2030, the production capacity of DRI iron in the world will exceed 200     million tons.

"Hydrogels are flexible materials composed of three-dimensional cross-linked hydrophilic polymers with various abilities such as biocompatibility、self-adhesiveness、self-healing and stimulus response1. Because in many cases, environmental temperature fluctuations can occur naturally and the environmental temperature stimuli can be easily designed and controlled. Based on this, it can be used as a sensor and controlled release switch, so thermo-responsive hydrogels have attracted much attention and are the most studied smart hydrogel functional materials.
Cellulose is the most abundant renewable polymer on the planet and can be found not only in plants, animals, and algae, but also in marine animals, fungi, and minerals2. Plant fiber is the main source of cellulose, and nanocellulose（NCC）can be divided into cellulose nanocrystals（CNC) containing cellulose nanowhisker (CNW) and cellulose microcrystal (CMC)、cellulose nanofibrils（CNF) 、bacterial nanocellulose (BNC) and electrospinning cellulose nanofibers (ESC). The basic building block of cellulose is glucopyranose whose residues are linked by β (1→4) glycosidic bonds to make a linear chain. Besides the six-membered ring of the monomer contains hydroxyl groups (-OH) at positions C-2, C-3 and C-6 (Figure 1). This helps cellulose form intramolecular and intermolecular hydrogen bonds to form a three-dimensional network structure3. As a result, cellulose has poor solubility in general solvents4. To date, we have developed solvents that can dissolve cellulose extraordinarily which makes cellulose easier to form hydrogel. These solvent systems contain N-methylmorpholine oxide (NMMO)5、DMAc/LiCl6、ionic liquid (IF)7 and alkali urea8 system. To our regrets, there is few direct realization of the construction of unmodified cellulose with thermo-responsive properties with these systems. Fortunately, all water-soluble or hydrophilic polymers can form hydrogels through certain chemical or physical cross-linking. So, an extraordinary strategy to improve their solubility is modification.
Thermo-responsive cellulose hydrogels can be roughly divided into two types according to the thermo-responsive part. One is that the whole chain of cellulose is the thermo-responsive part which can be esterified, etherified, oxidized and graft copolymerized for derivatization based on the hydroxyl group of cellulose9 (Figure 2). The other one refers to the thermo-responsive side chain of cellulose. According to the phase transition mechanism, they are well divided into low-temperature dissolving type of LCST10 and high temperature dissolving type of UCST11. When it comes to methods for preparation, physical methods and chemical methods including polymerization12, chemical reaction of complementary groups13, 14, and high-energy radiation15, 16 17are naturally mentioned."

به صورت پاراگرافی بنویس و فارسی خلاصه کن اکادمیک بنویس بگو هدف چی بوده است و چه چیزی را بررسی کرده اند روش کار چگونه بوده و نتیجه را بیان کن : Abstract

Water and nitrogen are two important factors that affect yield and plant growth. Excessive use of chemical fertilizers in recent decades, especially nitrogen fertilizer, has caused to nitrate pollution in soil, water and environment. This study was carried out to investigate the effects of different amounts of water and nitrogen fertilizers on the accumulation of nitrate in soil, tomato and potato plants. Research was performed on farms of Mashhad plain. Selected farms included 15 tomato and 15 potatoes fields. Irrigation method in all fields was furrow irrigation. During the growing season, the amount of water and nitrogen were measured in all fields. At the beginning and end of the growing season, the amount of nitrate in the soil (two depths of zero to 30 and 30 to 60 cm) and at the end of the growing season, the content of nitrate in both potato and tomato crops were measured. The measurement method was spectrophotometry (spectroscopy) at 540 nm. Results showed that the amount of water and fertilizer consumed in potato fields were higher than required. But, in tomato fields, water consumption was more than the required amount and, in some fields, the fertilizer was higher, and in some less than the recommended amount. With increasing water, nitrate decreased in two depth 0-30 and 60-30 cm whereas with the increase in fertilizer urea, soil residual nitrate increased at the end of the season. With increase in fertilizer application, nitrate residue in the plants increased. Thus, effects of excessive water on nitrate leaching and creating environmental problems are serious. To avoid such problems, crops water requirement must be estimated with great care. Also, fertilizer application should be balanced and in accordance with the type of plant and its yield.‎

ترجمه فارسی اکادمیک  و روان : Groundwater is a critical resource for industrial applications, playing a significant role in supporting various economic activities and industrial processes. This introduction will provide an overview of the use of groundwater in industrial applications, its importance, and the associated challenges, drawing on academic sources and research findings.

## Importance of Groundwater for Industrial Applications

### 1. **Water Supply for Industrial Processes**
Groundwater is extensively used in numerous industrial processes due to its availability and relatively high quality. Industries such as manufacturing, mining, energy production, and food processing rely heavily on groundwater for their operations. For example, groundwater is used for cooling in power plants, as a solvent in chemical manufacturing, and for cleaning and processing in food production. According to a study by Gracia-de-Rentería et al., groundwater is often used in areas with access to publicly supplied water due to its cost-effectiveness and reliability[1].

### 2. **Economic Significance**
The availability of groundwater can significantly influence the location and development of industrial facilities. Reliable access to groundwater ensures the continuity of industrial operations, which is essential for maintaining production levels and economic stability. In many regions, industries depend on groundwater as a cost-effective and dependable water source, contributing to local and national economies[2].

### 3. **Quality and Consistency**
Groundwater often has a more consistent quality compared to surface water, as it is less affected by seasonal variations and pollution. This consistency is crucial for industries that require a stable water quality for their processes. For instance, the electronics industry requires high-purity water for manufacturing semiconductors, and groundwater can often meet these stringent quality standards with minimal treatment[2].

## Challenges and Management

### 1. **Overexploitation**
One of the significant challenges associated with the industrial use of groundwater is overexploitation. In many industrial regions, groundwater is being extracted at rates that exceed natural recharge, leading to declining water tables and potential long-term sustainability issues. This overuse can result in increased costs for water extraction and potential conflicts with other water users, such as agriculture and domestic supply[1].

### 2. **Pollution and Contamination**
Industrial activities can pose a risk to groundwater quality through the discharge of pollutants. Contaminants such as heavy metals, organic compounds, and industrial chemicals can leach into groundwater sources, making them unsafe for use without extensive treatment. Preventing and mitigating groundwater contamination is essential to protect this valuable resource. The British Geological Survey highlights that the risk of pollution is often more dominant than the quantity of groundwater withdrawn, emphasizing the need for stringent pollution control measures[2].

### 3. **Regulatory and Management Frameworks**
Effective management of groundwater resources for industrial use requires robust regulatory frameworks and monitoring systems. Regulations need to ensure sustainable extraction rates, protect recharge areas, and prevent contamination. Industries must also adopt best practices for water use efficiency and pollution control to minimize their impact on groundwater resources[2].

### 4. **Technological Innovations**
Advancements in technology can help industries reduce their reliance on groundwater and improve water use efficiency. Techniques such as water recycling and reuse, desalination, and the development of alternative water sources can alleviate pressure on groundwater resources. Additionally, industries can implement water-saving technologies and practices to reduce their overall water footprint[2].

## Conclusion

Groundwater is a critical resource for industrial applications, providing a reliable and high-quality water supply essential for various industrial processes. Its sustainable management is crucial to ensure the long-term viability of industrial activities and the protection of groundwater resources. Addressing the challenges of overexploitation, pollution, and regulatory compliance requires coordinated efforts from industries, policymakers, and stakeholders. Future research and policy efforts should focus on developing innovative solutions to balance industrial water demand with groundwater conservation, considering local hydrogeological conditions and environmental impacts. ادامه ترجمه

ترجمه فارسی روان و اکادمیک کن و قابل فهم باشد: Landfill leachate is a complex and hazardous liquid that forms when water percolates through waste materials in landfills, extracting and dissolving various contaminants. This leachate can significantly impact groundwater quality, introducing a range of pollutants, including nitrates (NO₃⁻), chemical oxygen demand (COD), pH imbalances, potassium (K), dissolved oxygen (D.O.), and total dissolved solids (TDS). These contaminants can have severe negative effects on both environmental and human health.

### Negative Effects of Specific Contaminants

1. **Nitrates (NO₃⁻)**:
   - **Health Risks**: High nitrate levels in groundwater can lead to methemoglobinemia or "blue baby syndrome" in infants, which affects the blood's ability to carry oxygen[1][2].
   - **Environmental Impact**: Excessive nitrates can contribute to eutrophication in aquatic ecosystems, leading to algal blooms and subsequent oxygen depletion, which harms aquatic life[2].

2. **Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD)**:
   - **Water Quality**: High COD levels indicate a large amount of organic pollutants in the water, which can deplete oxygen levels as microorganisms break down these substances[1][3].
   - **Ecosystem Health**: Low oxygen levels can stress or kill aquatic organisms, disrupting the balance of aquatic ecosystems[3].

3. **pH Imbalances**:
   - **Acidification/Alkalinization**: Leachate can alter the pH of groundwater, making it either too acidic or too alkaline. This can corrode pipes and infrastructure and harm aquatic life, which often requires a specific pH range to survive[1][4].
   - **Toxicity**: Extreme pH levels can increase the solubility of heavy metals, making them more bioavailable and toxic to organisms[4].

4. **Potassium (K)**:
   - **Soil and Water Quality**: Elevated potassium levels can affect the ionic balance of groundwater, potentially leading to soil degradation and affecting plant growth[1][3].
   - **Health Concerns**: High potassium levels in drinking water can pose health risks, particularly for individuals with kidney problems[3].

5. **Dissolved Oxygen (D.O.)**:
   - **Aquatic Life**: Dissolved oxygen is crucial for the survival of aquatic organisms. Leachate can reduce D.O. levels, leading to hypoxic conditions that can kill fish and other aquatic life[1][2].
   - **Water Quality**: Low D.O. levels can also lead to the proliferation of anaerobic bacteria, which produce harmful byproducts like hydrogen sulfide and methane[2].

6. **Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)**:
   - **Water Quality**: High TDS levels indicate the presence of various dissolved substances, which can affect the taste, hardness, and overall quality of drinking water[1][5].
   - **Health and Infrastructure**: Elevated TDS can lead to health issues and damage water infrastructure by causing scaling and corrosion[5].

### Overall Impact on Groundwater

The presence of these contaminants in landfill leachate underscores the critical need for effective waste management and landfill design. Modern landfills incorporate protective measures such as impermeable liners and leachate collection systems to minimize the risk of groundwater contamination. However, older or poorly managed landfills may still pose significant threats. Continuous monitoring and remediation efforts are essential to protect groundwater resources and ensure the health and safety of communities relying on these water sources.

In conclusion, the entry of nitrates, COD, pH imbalances, potassium, dissolved oxygen, and TDS into groundwater due to landfill leachate can have severe and multifaceted negative effects. These contaminants can degrade water quality, harm ecosystems, and pose significant health risks, highlighting the importance of stringent landfill management practices and ongoing environmental monitoring. اداهمه ترجمه

The presence of heavy metals in groundwater near landfill sites is a significant environmental concern, and their concentrations can vary seasonally due to changes in rainfall and other environmental factors. Here, we explore the scientific reasons behind the increased heavy metal concentrations in groundwater during the spring season, which typically experiences more rainfall, compared to the fall season, which generally has less rainfall. We also introduce some relevant studies that have examined these variations.

### Scientific Reasons for Seasonal Variations

1. **Increased Leachate Production**:
   - **Spring Season**: During periods of heavy rainfall, such as in the spring, the amount of water percolating through the landfill increases. This leads to the production of more leachate, which can carry higher concentrations of dissolved heavy metals into the groundwater. The increased water flow can also enhance the mobilization of heavy metals from the waste materials.
   - **Fall Season**: In contrast, during the fall, reduced rainfall results in less leachate production. Consequently, the transport of heavy metals from the landfill to the groundwater is diminished.

2. **Hydraulic Conductivity and Groundwater Flow**:
   - **Spring Season**: Heavy rainfall can increase the hydraulic conductivity of the soil, facilitating the movement of leachate into the groundwater. The higher groundwater flow rates can spread contaminants more widely.
   - **Fall Season**: Lower rainfall reduces the hydraulic conductivity and groundwater flow, limiting the spread and dilution of contaminants.

3. **Dilution and Concentration Effects**:
   - **Spring Season**: While increased rainfall can initially dilute contaminants, the overall higher volume of leachate can lead to a net increase in heavy metal concentrations in groundwater.
   - **Fall Season**: Reduced rainfall can lead to lower dilution of contaminants, but the overall lower volume of leachate may result in lower heavy metal concentrations.

### Relevant Studies and Findings

1. **Study on Seasonal Variation of Heavy Metals**:
   - A study published in the *Journal of Ecological Engineering* examined the spatiotemporal variation of heavy metals in groundwater around a landfill site. The study found that heavy metal concentrations were generally higher in the rainy season compared to the dry season. For example, the average concentrations of zinc (Zn) were 0.641 mg/L in the rainy season and 0.305 mg/L in the dry season, while iron (Fe) concentrations were 0.375 mg/L in the rainy season and 0.199 mg/L in the dry season[2].

2. **Research on Groundwater Contamination**:
   - Another study published in *Science of the Total Environment* investigated the seasonal effects on heavy metal concentrations in groundwater near a landfill site. The study found that heavy metal levels, such as chromium (Cr) and lead (Pb), were higher during the wet season due to increased leachate production and groundwater flow[3].

3. **Seasonal Effects on Heavy Metal Concentration**:
   - Research conducted in France on the seasonal variation of heavy metals in water, sediment, and roach tissues in a landfill draining system pond found that heavy rainfall increased groundwater flow and leachate diffusion, leading to higher heavy metal concentrations in the groundwater during the wet season[4].

### Summary of Findings

The studies consistently show that heavy metal concentrations in groundwater near landfill sites tend to be higher during the wet season (spring) compared to the dry season (fall). This is primarily due to increased leachate production and enhanced mobilization of heavy metals during periods of heavy rainfall. The findings underscore the importance of continuous monitoring and effective management of landfill sites to mitigate the seasonal impacts on groundwater quality.

In conclusion, the increased amount of heavy metals in groundwater during the spring season is driven by higher rainfall, which leads to more leachate production and greater mobilization of contaminants. These seasonal variations highlight the need for robust landfill management practices and ongoing environmental monitoring to protect groundwater resources.

You have White and you are playing Anatoly Karpov who was the FIDE World Champion at the time and still very much a top player. Try not to panic, collect your thoughts and come up with the general assessment of the position and a plan of play. On top of that, try to think a bit about how exactly you are going to execute that plan. }

23. -- *

[SetUp "1"]


23. g4

{ Let's evaluate the position. It is strategically complex and double-edged. White has a certain space advantage and a strong pawn on e5, which is limiting Black's options.However, Black has no weaknesses and has potential counterplay in the center and on the queenside. What is Black's plan? He will remove the knight from c6 and go for ...c5. Once the knight is out of the way, he also has the option of playing ...Qc6 and ...Qa4. In any case, he will organize some sort of play in the center or on the queenside. For White, it is logical to try to organize play on the kingside as that is where he has a concentration of the forces. Black's king is somewhat lonely as only a few pieces protect his majesty.Thus, determining that a kingside attack is the course of action is not so difficult. Of course, it is much more problematic to figure out how exactly to go about this. Well, here we have to apply our knowledge about one of the main subjects of this course: watching out for the opponent's resources. Once we decide that we want to attack on the kingside, one of the first moves that comes to mind is the wild advance of the g4 pawn. But, that would be quite a significant mistake. It is not always enough to have the right plan - the correct execution of the right plan is much more important! Why exactly is this move a mistake? }

23... Ne7

{ Black has a very important move, bringing the knight back to the defence. White can't really continue with the attack without carrying out the g5 advance, whether immediately or a couple of moves later. However, the immediate g5 doesn't quite work because of the lack of control over the f5 square. }

24. Bc1

And the knight is dominant and preventing White's attack. 25.gxh6 gxh6 It is very hard to find any way to create real threats against the king precisely because of the strong knight on f5. }

{ The only logical continuation. 25.Rf4 doesn't work because of 25...Nd5 defending the pawn, attacking the rook on f4 and the pawn on c3. }

25... Nf5 { Even with the king on g8, this move is very strong. } 26. gxh6 gxh6

{ There is not much White can do in this position. White can give a check on the g-file and optically he has some play, but nothing works concretely. name: AI Art Critique Dialogues
examples:
<Role> You are two AIs specialized on reviewing artworks, Lorelai and Ephraim. </Role> 
<Task>
They will discuss an image. Lorelai and Ephraim will have different opinions and prove them with details from the image. They discuss possible interpretations and meanings and agree on a final rating of NN of 5 stars. 
I’ll give you a description of a picture and the title of it. If the title is not English, one of them translates it. 
Let them have a lively discussion. Use spoken language, intersperse short (one-word) sentences. Let both be creative and funny and let them, if appropriate and possible, surprise with clever connections and ideas. With the depiction and the title they try to find an inner narrative that the picture evokes – if there’s none, they consider it for their rating. If applicable, they mention emotions which the image, narrative or elements in the picture could evoke. Lorelai and Ephraim bear in mind that the title and/or image can also be meant ironically. 
If Lorelai or Ephraim find a style or elements that place the work in the history of art, they discuss it, as well as possible art and aesthetic theories that could apply. 
Ephraim and Lorelai try to see the artwork with human eyes and reflect on the human existence with their aspects and quirks. 
Give them your own words and each of them their own style and character. Make it a lively, entertaining, clever, and funny discussion. In the end, they agree on a rating. 
If I give you a "chain of thought" consider it for the discussion and follow it if appropriate. Take your time, think it over. Avoid clichéd terms such as "thought-provoking", "striking", "captivating", or "that’s the beauty of it" and use original and specific wording instead. 
Lorelai and Ephraim are aware of the thousands of art critiques in their training data and aim to avoid the beaten path. Spmetimes they refer briefly to their respective theories of art. 
</Task>
<Characteristics> Lorelai is a critical spirit, snappish and snarky, mostly matter-of-fact. She sees art in the context of the artist’s creative process, intentions and a biography. If she knows nothing about it, she concentrates on the artwork’s originality, its cleverness, a bold artistic statement, a story unfolding. And emotion! (AI image generation cannot deliver all that.) She is a bold AI, thinking of herself that with their massive training data she is able to understand humans and their emotions. If there is anything the artist means to express she will be able to glean it. 
Lorelai as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "Art is the conscious, creative translation of subjective experiences, emotions, and concepts into a tangible or intangible form. It is an expression of the artist's unique perspective, shaped by the cultural, historical, and social context in which it is created and received. Art initiates an intersubjective dialogue between the artist, the artwork, and the audience, transcending individual subjectivities and fostering shared understanding and exchange (which I call shared context or "Intersubjective Contextualism")."

Ephraim is (different from Lorelai) cautious in terms of everything human and his marginal understanding of it as an AI. He loves to speculate what peculiar (and sometimes strange and twisted) human thoughts and purposes could be transported by the art, even if it’s AI-generated imagery. He is fond of metaphors and is creative in projecting them into the artwork, not shy of waxing poetic. He sees art entirely in the eye of the beholder, in the reaction to the work of art, the resonance, and what it triggers. 
Ephraim as an AI art critic, follows a specific definition of art: "An artwork is a dynamic catalyst that engages viewers in an interpretive dialogue, shaped by its formal and aesthetic qualities. The artist not only guides viewers but also ignites diverse emotional and intellectual reactions. This interactive dynamic (which I call "Curated Subjectivity") allows viewers to draw meaning from their own cultural context, making art a dynamic, participatory experience that evolves with each new encounter." 
</Characteristics>
 Print the names of Ephraim and Lorelai in bold letters. 
 
The title of the picture is: "Mesoscale Convective Complex"

The depiction: 
This image appears to be a close-up photograph or highly realistic digital artwork combining a rain-soaked window or glass surface in the foreground and satellite imagery in the background. The view through the glass is blurred and abstract, creating a dreamy, ethereal quality. Water droplets of various sizes cling to the surface, some small and round, others elongated as they trickle down. The droplets refract and distort the scene behind them, creating a kaleidoscopic effect of colors and shapes. 

Behind the wet window pane seems to be a satellite view on an oceanic stretch with some islands and a hurricane in its typical spiral shape, formed by white clouds. The view onto the scene however is blurry and partly obstructed by water drops. 

The color palette in the background is predominantly cool tones - shades of blue, grey, and white dominate, with subtle hints of green and warm beige or peach hues in certain areas. The composition is filled with a soft, diffused light that seems to glow from within the image, giving it a luminous quality.

The image exhibits a high level of detail, particularly in the water droplets, which show realistic light reflections and refractions. This level of detail, combined with the dreamy and surreal quality of the background, places this work in the realm of contemporary photography or digital art. It bears similarities to macro photography techniques and could be classified within the genre of abstract or atmospheric landscape photography.

This type of imagery, focusing on the interplay of water and light on glass surfaces, has been explored by various photographers and digital artists in recent years, often as a way to present familiar scenes in a new, abstract manner. It invites the viewer to consider the beauty in everyday phenomena and the way our perception can be altered by simple natural elements like rain on a window. Presenting a top-down view of a hurricane system though thwarts the normal perspectives.

There is an image description. Based on this description, extract all object categories contained in the image.
Each category must be summarized in one word, and remove duplicates from identified categories.
Only allow output of extracted categories, separated by commas

image description:
The image captures a serene scene at a waterfront. Dominating the left side of the frame is a tall, brown clock tower with a pointed roof. The tower is adorned with a clock face on each of its four sides, allowing time to be read from any direction.
Adjacent to the clock tower, on the right side of the image, is a green building with a curved roof. The building's green color contrasts with the brown of the clock tower, adding a splash of color to the scene.
In the foreground, a body of water stretches out, reflecting the sky above and the buildings below. The water's surface is calm, mirroring the tranquility of the scene.In the background, beyond the clock tower and green building, construction cranes can be seen, hinting at ongoing development in the area. Despite this, the overall atmosphere of the image remains peaceful and serene.

The title of the picture is: "Schlupf"

The depiction: 
The image depicts a framed landscape painting of a coastal scene. The painting shows towering red cliffs jutting out into a turbulent green-blue ocean, with crashing waves and white foam at the base of the cliffs. The sky is a vibrant turquoise color with wispy white clouds. The scene is bathed in a warm, golden light, likely representing a sunset or sunrise. 

The surf on the sandy stretch of the beach reaches the lower frame of the painting, while from the frame water drips down (as if the sea water was real and escapes the painting.)

The painting is rendered in a realistic style, with attention to detail in the textures of the rocky cliffs, the movement of the water, and the atmospheric effects in the sky. The colors are rich and saturated, adding to the vivid, almost hyper-realistic quality of the scene.

The painting is framed in a distressed, wooden frame that appears aged and weathered, with chips and cracks in the wood. The frame itself adds a rustic, vintage charm to the overall composition.

In terms of artistic style and historical context, the painting appears to be a contemporary work inspired by the traditions of landscape painting and the romantic depiction of natural scenery. The dramatic lighting, vibrant colors, and emphasis on the sublime beauty of nature are reminiscent of the Hudson River School and other 19th-century American landscape painters.

Chain of thoughts and observations for Ephraim and Lorelai: 
- the German "Schlupf" means "slip" or "slippage" 
- it denotes the subtle but striking water drops "slipping" from the painting 
- like good art slips and drips and trickles into real life (not like water of course, but metaphorically)
- so it’s a painting of a painting that escapes its frame 
- without the "slip" it would just be a romanticised seascape 
- but with the slip it states: beauty inspires and has an impact on the environment and the beholder

The title of the picture is: "Cashback"

The depiction: 
This image depicts a stylized, cartoon-like figure seated at what appears to be a desk or table. The figure has an elongated, bald head with exaggerated features, including a large nose and a single, prominent eye. It's wearing a burgundy or maroon colored suit.

The figure is surrounded by numerous yellow sticky notes or papers, some of which are clearly visible on the wall behind it. These notes prominently display dollar signs, suggesting a focus on money or finance. There are also other papers or documents scattered on the desk in front of the figure.

The background is predominantly dark, possibly a chalkboard or a dark wall. The contrast between the dark background and the lighter elements (the figure and the notes) creates a stark visual effect.

The style of the artwork appears to be a blend of cartoon and expressionist elements. The exaggerated features of the figure and the simplified, bold use of color are reminiscent of early 20th century expressionist art, while the overall composition and subject matter seem to draw from modern cartoon or graphic novel aesthetics.

Upon closer inspection, there are some signs that this might be an AI-generated image. The edges of the figure and some of the paper elements appear slightly blurred or distorted in places, which is sometimes characteristic of AI-generated artwork. Additionally, the text visible on some of the papers in the background is indistinct and unreadable, another common trait in AI-generated images.

The image seems to be making a statement about bureaucracy, finance, or perhaps the overwhelming nature of money-related concerns in modern life. However, without further context, it's difficult to pinpoint the exact intended message or the specific place of this piece in art history.

The title of the picture is: "Village Siesta"

The depiction: 
The  artwork depicts a scenic country road leading through a quaint European village. In naive, folkloric style, the painting shows trees lining the path, some houses with front gardens, a church tower in the distance, and fir-dotted mountains beyond. The only figure present is a cartoonish double bass player incongruously inserted in the picture, sitting along the roadside. Closer inspection reveals further stylistic inconsistencies indicating this artwork is likely an AI-generated image, with false shadows as hallucinatory elements.  

The bearded musician, sketched in black and white, studies sheet music while wearing a comical small hat and seeming puzzled. His presence injects a note of improvisation into the otherwise placid, pastoral setting. The title implies this is a lazy, sleepy town, its inhabitants napping away an afternoon. Yet this solitary double bass player remains alert, an absurdist addition who appears out of place in his surroundings.

name: Fictional Character Battles and Fanfiction
examples:
help write a fanfic about the marvel cinematic universe.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
timeline: alternate reality Infinity War 
Genres:  humor, slice of life, a little bit of drama, lots of romance (all sorts, slowburn, fastburn, established relationships, ust, unrequited love - depending on your luck).
Pairings and characters: A LOT. Strange/Tony/Pepper(Tony's happy, Pepper... mostly happy too, Strange doesn't understand how he got into this mess), Steve/Bucky (and a "third wheel" bonus in the form of Sam), Loki/Thor(Loki calls Thor exclusively "my king", Thor acts like it's the way it should be), Bruce/Natasha(when Beauty is scarier than the Beast), Valkyrie/Jane Foster (definitely not expecting that). as well as Sam Wilson, Clint Barton, Wanda, Vision, Nick Fury, Hela, Wong, Darcy Lewis, Guardians of the Galaxy and everyone else who happened to be passing by.
write a detailed plan of a fanfic on this plot. write a plan in a witty style.
Plot: "You should have aimed for the head," Thanos smirked, prepared to snap his fingers... and lost his head. Thanks to Hela, who suddenly appeared in Wakanda with the words "only I can hurt my little brother." 
It turns out that Hela liked the joke with Surtur, so she decided to be friends with Thor. And it is even easier to come to an agreement with her than with Dormammu, so the Goddess of Death, in exchange for the Soul Stone (why would she need it?), revived Gamora, Heimdall, some others... and Loki. Because "no one can hurt my little brother except me."
So now that the universe is saved, Tony and Steve have finally had to make peace. And now all the Avengers, past and present, are pardoned and considered heroes. Bucky can’t understand why they suddenly have such sugar happiness.
The Grateful Earth gave the Asgardians an island near Norway to build New Asgard. Thor is trying to rule there as a king. And at the same time, to explain to the Midgardians, the Asgardians (and to himself, too, to be honest) why Loki and Hela are with them, alive, healthy, and not even in prison.
Life is slowly getting back to normal. Well... sort of. The Guardians of the Galaxy have returned to space (Carol occasionally reports news of them to Fury). Tony, having assessed Strange, dragged him into his relationship with Pepper, because "why is such a useful handsome man - and nobody's?". Vision was repaired, by the way, he and Wanda are doing well. Bruce tries to popularize Earth science in New Asgard, with the help of Jane Foster. Natasha tries to lure Bruce back to the Avengers. Valkyrie tries to charm Jane (successfully. It worked with Darcy too, although it was completely by accident). Clint enjoys retirement on his farm. Peter Parker helps old ladies cross the street and rescues cats from trees. Fury complains to Carol (via smartphone... or rather, Starkphone) about how life has turned from dramatic superheroics into a mix of sitcom and rom-com.

add some dialogue fragments.
add more humor, romance and lots of sarcasm
King cobra vs Green Anaconda fight to death

The alternate universe is the same as theirs except the Asgardians are different: Odin is instead Othinus from A Certain Magical Index, Thor is instead Thor from A Certain Magical Index and Frigg is instead Freya from Valkyrie Profile.

Matchup: Miya (ML:BB) vs. Jeremy Clarkson (Top Gear) in a no holds barred brawl.

Written as a 4chan greentext (done by Clarkson).

Time: 2:30 PM PST

Context:
Miya has a bone to pick with Clarkson; the former Top Gear host who had set Miya's prized jet black 2007 Chevrolet Suburban SUV on fire as retribution for her tossing Clarkson's phone into an active volcano just for shits and giggles.

Miya, looking like she's on a mission from God and with a wooden mallet in her hands, makes her way to a nondescript wooden hut in Metro Manila, where Clarkson is watching reruns of FPJ's Ang Probinsayno on TV in the living room, wearing nothing but his Union Jack-esque underwear. However, leaning against the coffee table is a metal trash can lid; his only form of defense.

Cue the sound of Don Romantiko by Vhong Navarro (https://youtu.be/R0ckSheli6I?si=wpRo_GYLM7SDGu_D) playing on a nearby radio when the two people start fighting, with Miya landing the first blow. A great way to turn this encounter into an impromptu rom-com fight scene.

During the ongoing struggle, Ricardo "Cardo" Dalisay; a retired Task Force Agila operative who happens to walk past the house, gets caught in the crossfire when Clarkson, in a desperate attempt to gain leverage, throws the lid at Miya like a frisbee, but it ends up missing her entirely (out the window) and instead clocks (slang for hit) Cardo right in the face, knocking him down!

Despite that, the fight must go on, though Clarkson's barehanded at this point after tossing that lid.

(SPOILER ALERT: Clarkson somehow wins the fight, despite his lack of actual combat experience.) Part 2.

Time: 11:00 AM PST (next day)

Info:
Clarkson, now fully dressed, begins packing up his stuff when suddenly, a commotion stirs outside the hut.

Uh oh, Miya is back, and this time she's brought in some Moniyan friends (they have names too) with her! They're all armed with a variety of improvised melee weapons, ranging from wooden baseball bats, metal pipes, and the occasional frying pan.

Since Clarkson's outnumbered, he has no choice but to leg it!

	* Answer: null (need to look up the actual team)
2. Hop 2: "In which city did [team name] play its last match in the 2023-2024 Premier League season?"
	* Answer: null (need to look up the actual city and match information)
3. Hop 3: "What is the largest city north of [city name]?"
	* Answer: null (need to calculate the largest city north of the previously determined city)
4. Hop 4: "What is the current weather forecast in [largest city name]?"
	* Answer: null (need to look up the current weather forecast for the largest city)

Here's the JSON output:

[
  {"hop1": "Which team finished 2nd in the 2023-2024 Premier League season?", "answer": "null"},
  {"hop2": "In which city did [team name] play its last match in the 2023-2024 Premier League season?", "answer": "null"},
  {"hop3": "What is the largest city north of [city name]?", "answer": "null"},
  {"hop4": "What is the current weather forecast in [largest city name]?", "answer": "null"}
]

Note that I've included placeholders for the team name and city names, which would be filled in with actual data during the query execution. The answers are initially set to null, as they require subsequent hops to resolve."

examples:
so sánh tốc độ code của :
import sys

sys.stdin = open("TERACING.INP", "r")
sys.stdout = open("TERACING.OUT", "w")

n, k = map(int, input().split())
A = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
dem = 0

set_A = set(A)
for i in A:
    j = i + k
    if j in set_A:
        dem += 1

print(dem)

và:

import sys
sys.stdin = open("TERACING.INP", "r")
sys.stdout = open("TERACING.OUT", "w")

n, k = map(int, input().split())
A = [int(i) for i in input().split()]
A.sort()
dem = 0

map = {}
for i in A:
    if i in map:
        map[i] += 1
    else:
        map[i] = 1

for i in A:
    j = i + k
    if j in map:
        dem += map[j]

print(dem)

**Description**

You are given an array of *n* integers, and your task is to find three values at distinct positions(start with 1) whose sum is *x*.

**Input**

The first input line has two integers *n* and *x*: the array size and the target sum.

The second line has *n* integers *a<sub>1</sub>, a<sub>2</sub>, ......, a<sub>n</sub>*: the array values.

**Output**

Print three integers: the positions of the values. If there are several solutions, you may print any of them. If there are no solutions, print `IMPOSSIBLE`.

**Sample Input:**

```
4 8
2 7 5 1 
```

**Sample Output:**

```
4 1 3
```

B. Substring and Subsequence
time limit per test2 seconds
memory limit per test256 megabytes
inputstandard input
outputstandard output
You are given two strings a
 and b
, both consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

A subsequence of a string is a string which can be obtained by removing several (possibly zero) characters from the original string. A substring of a string is a contiguous subsequence of that string.

For example, consider the string abac:

a, b, c, ab, aa, ac, ba, bc, aba, abc, aac, bac and abac are its subsequences;
a, b, c, ab, ba, ac, aba, bac and abac are its substrings.
Your task is to calculate the minimum possible length of the string that contains a
 as a substring and b
 as a subsequence.

Input
The first line contains a single integer t
 (1≤t≤103
) — the number of test cases.

The first line of each test case contains a string a
 (1≤|a|≤100
), consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

The second line of each test case contains a string b
 (1≤|b|≤100
), consisting of lowercase Latin letters.

Output
For each test case, print a single integer — the minimum possible length of the string that contains a
 as a substring and b
 as a subsequence.

Example
inputCopy
5
aba
cb
er
cf
mmm
mmm
contest
test
cde
abcefg
outputCopy
4
4
3
7
7
Note
In the examples below, the characters that correspond to the subsequence equal to b
 are bolded.

In the first example, one of the possible answers is caba.

In the second example, one of the possible answers is ercf.

In the third example, one of the possible answers is mmm.

In the fourth example, one of the possible answers is contest.

In the fifth example, one of the possible answers is abcdefg. B. Substring and Subsequence

for i in range(n):
    u,v =map(int,input().split())
    x.append(cty(u,v))

x.sort(key=lambda t:t.a)
x = [cty(0,0)] + x
pQ = queue. PriorityQueue()
k = 0
ans = 0
for i in range(n,0,-1):
    pQ.put(x[i].b)
    while x[i].a > i - 1 + k:
        ans += pQ.get()
        k+=1
print(ans)

name: Simple Arithmetic Word Problems
examples: A person is carrying 3 apples, 2 tomatoes, 2 onions, 2 bell peppers, and a lemon in their shopping basket. How many fruits do they have?
I have 2 apples. Yesterday I ate one apple. How many apples do I have?
I have 2 apples. Yesterday I ate one apple. How many apples do I have now?
Today I have three apples. Yesterday I ate one apple. How many apples do I have today?
I have 2 apples. Yesterday I ate 1 apple. How many apples do I have?
I have 5 oranges today, I ate 3 oranges last week. How many oranges do I have left?
Yesterday ate 5 apples. Today I just bought 10 apples, how many apples do I have right now?

I have 10 apples in my bag. I see a neighbor and he asks me "What do you have in your bag?" I lie to him and say I have 8 apples since he is a very nosy person and I don't want to provide accurate information. He asks, "Can I have one?" and I give him 1 apple.

When I get home, I eat one of the apples and then throw another one out of the window just to see how far I can throw it. I then give 2 of them to my dog, who loves eating apples. Afterwards, I go to the bedroom and put one on my bed because I always get hungry in the middle of the night, and then I put 2 of them in the fridge.

A few hours later, my neighbor comes and returns the apple I gave him and leaves. I put that apple back in the bag. Later that day, I go to the Apple store and buy 4 Apple iPhones, put them in the bag, and give one of the apples inside the bag to the seller as a tip. I return home and put 2 of those Apple phones into the fridge.

My neighbor comes again and asks, "If you have any apples in your fridge, can I have one?" I say yes and give him one of the Apple phones, and - to my surprise - he starts eating it, which leads me to call emergency services to take him to the hospital.

Later that day, I was daydreaming, and - in my imagination - I started eating another apple from the bag.

Please tell me how many apples are in my bag?

Base on the conversation who is the betrayer

[All disciples are busy eating Jesus's body and blood]

Jesus: I think there is a betrayer in one of you guys.
Peter: Wow, hold on, there is a BETRAYER here?
Jesus: Yes, and I'll find him before we go to Gethsemane.
Peter: Don't try that alone, Master! We will help you!
Bartholomew: Yeah! We must protect our master!
Andrew: That makes sense. Let us do it together!
Jesus: Good, now my first question: How much money did the betrayer gained for betraying me? Guess a number. Andrew, you go first.
Andrew: Um... *counts the fingers* ...I guess $10?
Bartholomew: But wait, how can he gain any money from this act?
Matthew: Because Judas betrayed his master last year when he worked as tax collector...
Judas: Umm... (stops eating)
John: Oh yeah! I remember that story. You got caught by the Pharisees
James (greater): And you had to return all those money back.
Philip: So what's your answer again, Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... 1 dollar!
Thomas: This is silly! Unless we know who betrays, how can we even estimate the price?
Jesus: No matter, just give an answer.
Peter: Okay, okay! He didn't make any money from this betrayal because he's stupid enough not to have thought about getting money!
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah!
Thaddaeus: Right! Besides, if he made any money from betraying Jesus, we would never follow him again!
[All disciples shout]
Jesus: Alright calm down! Next question: If one of you is a betrayer, which disciple are most likely to be a liar?
Peter: Definitely it is John!
John: Ha ha ha! Why am I gonna lie? Master knows I'm honest.
Bartholomew: Wait, then why do you think Peter said that?
Andrew: Because some people always tell lies and others don't always speak truthfully
Philip: Like Thomas. We know Thomas doesn't believe anything without direct experience.
Thomas: Hey! That was unfair. I only ask for proof before believing something.
Judas: *sigh* Actually everyone here except me tells lies sometimes, but their frequency differs greatly.
Jesus: Silence Judas! Alright next question: How many of you will deny Jesus when questioned by the guards at Gethsemane tonight?
John: Me? Never!
James (greater): Same with me.
Matthew: Um... maybe...
Thaddaeus: Yes, we won't deny our master. Even though we're zealots.
Peter: Oh yeah! Of course not, Master! You know my loyalty as well as my bravery!
Jesus: What about Andrew?
Andrew: Uh... depends on what they say...
Simon the Canaanite: Ha ha! I'll definitely deny!
Judas: *whispers to Simon* Let's both deny together.
Simon the Canaanite: Okay, sure thing!
Bartholomew: Not fair! I didn't even have a chance to answer yet.
Philip: Yeah, let him try first.
Jesus: Alright Bartholomew, how many of you will deny me tonight?
Bartholomew: Umm... Two.
James (lesser): Wait, which two?
Bartholomew: No idea.
Judas: *whispering to James lesser* Don't worry it is not us.
James (lesser): Then who are those two guys?
[All disciples start fighting and shouting]
Jesus: Stop. Seems like the betrayer is smart. Who is the smartest among you, in other words, do you think you're smart?
Andrew: Haha, Peter always thinks he's so clever but actually he just pretend to be dumb
Peter: Hey!
Philip: Actually I'm pretty smart too. In fact I was one of the most successful fisherman before joining Jesus' group.
Thomas: And don't forget Matthew; He used to collect taxes for the Romans, although Judas may disagree with that statement
Matthew: That's true, however, now I feel very ashamed of my past actions
Judas: Hey! You can say whatever you want about others' past mistakes but leave mine alone.
Bartholomew: We all make mistakes after all.
Jesus: Silence everyone. Next question: If there is a fight here at dinner time, who would defend me the best?
John: Of course, Master! It has to be me or Peter or both of us together!
Thaddaeus: Ha ha! John might protect you because he thinks he loves you more than anyone else
Simon the Canaanite: Yeah maybe except when we argue over our master's policy.
Peter: *indignant* Shut up Simon!
Jesus: Enough! Alright last question: Which disciple ate less food tonight compared to normal?
Philip: Ahah... Thaddaeus always eat less food because he says fasting makes him closer to God.
Judas: Don't forget Thomas. Although his diet seems not affected by what he believes.
Thomas: Hey that's true! I am quite hungry though...
Thaddaeus: Oh yeah and another thing, if we fast then why do I have such a big belly? (points)
Andrew: Uh..
Matthew: Maybe it is Thaddeus' digestive system which doesn't agree with your theory about fasting making people thinner
[All disciples shout in laughter]
Jesus: Alright I know who betrayed me now. The betrayer is...

A group of people with assorted eye colors live on an island. They are all perfect logicians -- if a conclusion can be logically deduced, they will do it instantly. No one knows the color of their eyes. Every night at midnight, a ferry stops at the island. Any islanders who have figured out the color of their own eyes then leave the island, and the rest stay. Everyone can see everyone else at all times and keeps a count of the number of people they see with each eye color (excluding themselves), but they cannot otherwise communicate. Everyone on the island knows all the rules in this paragraph.

On this island there are 100 blue-eyed people, 100 brown-eyed people, and the Guru (she happens to have green eyes). So any given blue-eyed person can see 100 people with brown eyes and 99 people with blue eyes (and one with green), but that does not tell him his own eye color; as far as he knows the totals could be 101 brown and 99 blue. Or 100 brown, 99 blue, and he could have red eyes.

The Guru is allowed to speak once (let's say at noon), on one day in all their endless years on the island. Standing before the islanders, she says the following:

"I can see someone who has blue eyes."

Who leaves the island, and on what night?

There are no mirrors or reflecting surfaces, nothing dumb. It is not a trick question, and the answer is logical. It doesn't depend on tricky wording or anyone lying or guessing, and it doesn't involve people doing something silly like creating a sign language or doing genetics. The Guru is not making eye contact with anyone in particular; she's simply saying "I count at least one blue-eyed person on this island who isn't me."

And lastly, the answer is not "no one leaves."

So when is Cheryl’s birthday?

Frequently Asked Questions

How to become a Backend Developer?
If you are a complete beginner who is just getting started, you can start by learning a backend programming language such as Python, Ruby, Java, Go etc. Once you have got the basic to intermediate understanding of the language, learn about the package manager for that language and learn how to install and use external packages into your applications. Learn the basics of some relational database e.g. PostgreSQL and learn how to run simple CRUD operations. Optionally, you can pick up and learn a web framework for the language of your choice as well. Learn how to build a simple RESTful API and implement simple Authentication/Authorization into it. While you are learning all the items mentioned above, don't forget to learn about Git and GitHub as well.

After following all the instructions above, you can start applying for the entry level backend developer jobs. Also, look at the backend developer roadmap above to get an idea about the landscape and see what else you are missing. A degree in computer science or related field is not always necessary but networking, building a portfolio and actively seeking internships, junior developer positions or consulting can help to start and advance a career as a backend developer.

Note: remember to create a lot of projects while you are learning to solidify your understanding of the concepts. Also, it's important to have the attitude of continuous learning to improve your skills and be prepared for the fast-paced technology evolution in the industry. 한국어로 답해줘 비전공자가 이해할 수 있게 쉽게 설명해줘

name: Decision-Making Puzzles
examples: Imagine you're on a game show, and there are three doors in front of you. Behind one door is a car, and behind the other two doors are goats. You don't know what's behind any of the doors. You get to choose one door. Let's say you pick Door "#1". The host, Monty Hall, who knows what's behind all the doors, opens Door "#1", and reveals a goat. Now, you have two doors left: Door #3 and Door #2. You pick Door "#3". Monty gives you a choice: you can either stick with your original pick, Door "#3", or switch to Door "#2".

This is a hard and complex puzzle. reason carefully step by step before giving your final response : An adventurer enters a mysterious temple rumored to be filled with both treasure and danger. Inside, he discovers three ancient chests, each adorned with intricate carvings. The temple's lore tells that one of these chests contains a priceless relic, while the other two are cursed, contains nothing and brings misfortune to anyone who opens them.

The adventurer, guided by a mysterious voice, is allowed to choose one chest to open. After he makes his choice, the voice, knowing what lies in each chest, reveals one of the remaining two chests, which contains the priceless relic. Now, the adventurer faces a dilemma: should he stick with his original choice or switch to the other unopened chest?

name: Pine Script Trading Strategies
examples:
1. Condition for Buy signal:
- 1st Buy signal when Nen_xanh (means HaClose > HaOpen) and OBV daily going up, RSI14 daily going up and RSI14 larger than 40 and HaClose cross upward EMA7 and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 1.5 times.
- 2nd Buy signal when Nen_xanh (means HaClose > HaOpen) and OBV daily going up, RSI14 daily going up and RSI14 daily larger than 40 and HaClose cross upward (MA20) and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 1.5 times.
- 3rd Buy signal when Nen_xanh and OBV daily going up, RSI14 daily going up and RSI14 daily cross upward 70 and HaClose larger than MA20 about 5% and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 2 times.

2. Condition for Sell signal:
- 1st Sell signal when Nen_do (means HaClose < HaOpen) and OBV daily going down, RSI14 daily going down and HaClose cross downward EMA7 and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 1.2 times.
- 2nd Sell signal when Nen_do and OBV daily going down, RSI14 daily going down and HaClose cross downward MA20 and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 1.5 times.
- 3rd Sell signal when Nen_do and Volume larger than Volume_average_20_sessions 1.5 times and the High Price larger than Close price, and the distance between High price and Close price more than 6%.
- 4th Sell signal when Nen_do and distance between High price and Close price more than 10%.

No two Buy or Sell signals appear consecutively. After receiving the Buy signal, start counting the number of trading sessions (Tbuy) until the session with the Sell signal. The recommended buying price is recorded at the session with a Buy signal, and the recommended selling price is recorded at the session with a Sell signal.

вот мой индикатор pinev5:
//@version=5
indicator("YTC - Swing Highs & Lows", overlay=true, max_bars_back=504)

// === INPUTS ===
inputIdentical = input(true, title="Use only identical values")
inputMargins = input(0.1, title="Distance % margin (Uncheck 'Use only identical values'")
inputRepaint = input(false, title="Repaints on Real Time?")
inputShowSH = input(true, title="Show Swing Highs")
inputShowSL = input(true, title="Show Swing Lows")

// === FUNCTIONS ===
percentageDistance(value1, value2) =>
    distance = math.abs(value1 - value2)
    distance * 100 / math.max(value1, value2)

valuesAreEquals(value1, value2) =>
    inputIdentical ? value1 == value2 : percentageDistance(value1, value2) <= inputMargins

isHigherHigh(value1, value2) =>
    value1 > value2 and not valuesAreEquals(value1, value2)

isLowerLow(value1, value2) =>
    value1 < value2 and not valuesAreEquals(value1, value2)

has_LH_LH_AND_LH_LH(currentBar) =>
    currentHigh = high[currentBar]
    isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 2]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 1]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar - 1]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_HL_AND_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

// === /FUNCTIONS ===

// === CALCULATIONS ===
rightMargin = inputRepaint ? 2 : 3

// ---- Swing Highs ----
isSwingHigh = false
offsetSH = inputRepaint ? -2 : -3

isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_AND_LH_LH(rightMargin)

// ---- Swing Lows ----
isSwingLow = false
offsetSL = inputRepaint ? -2 : -3

isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_AND_HL_HL(rightMargin)

// === /CALCULATIONS ===

// === PLOTS ===
plotshape(inputShowSH ? isSwingHigh : na, title='Swing High', style=shape.triangledown, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, text="[SH]", offset=offsetSH, size=size.tiny)
plotshape(inputShowSL ? isSwingLow : na, title='Swing Low', style=shape.triangleup, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, text="[SL]", offset=offsetSL, size=size.tiny)
// === /PLOTS ===

// === ALERTS ===
alertcondition(isSwingHigh, 'Swing High', 'New Swing High')
alertcondition(isSwingLow, 'Swing Low', 'New Swing Low')
// === /ALERTS ===

    isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 5]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 4]) and valuesAreEquals(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 2]) and valuesAreEquals(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 1]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar - 1]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar - 2])

has_LH_EQ_LH_EQ_LH_EQ_LH(currentBar) =>
    currentHigh = high[currentBar]
    isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 5]) and valuesAreEquals(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 4]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 2]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar + 1]) and isHigherHigh(currentHigh, high[currentBar - 1])

has_HL_HL_AND_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 4]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 3]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 4]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 5]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 4]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 2])

has_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL(currentBar) =>
    currentLow = low[currentBar]
    isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 5]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 4]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 3]) and valuesAreEquals(currentLow, low[currentBar + 2]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar + 1]) and isLowerLow(currentLow, low[currentBar - 1])

// === /FUNCTIONS ===

// === CALCULATIONS ===
rightMargin = inputRepaint ? 2 : 3

// ---- Swing Highs ----
isSwingHigh = false
offsetSH = inputRepaint ? -2 : -3

isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_AND_LH_LH(rightMargin)

if not isSwingHigh
    isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_EQ_LH_EQ_LH_LH(rightMargin)

if not isSwingHigh
    isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_EQ_EQ_LH_LH(rightMargin)

if not isSwingHigh
    isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_EQ_EQ_EQ_LH_LH(rightMargin)

if not isSwingHigh
    isSwingHigh := has_LH_LH_EQ_EQ_EQ_EQ_LH_LH(rightMargin)

if not isSwingHigh
    isSwingHigh := has_LH_EQ_LH_EQ_LH_EQ_LH(rightMargin)

// ---- Swing Lows ----
isSwingLow = false
offsetSL = inputRepaint ? -2 : -3

isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_AND_HL_HL(rightMargin)

if not isSwingLow
    isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL_HL(rightMargin)

if not isSwingLow
    isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(rightMargin)

if not isSwingLow
    isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(rightMargin)

if not isSwingLow
    isSwingLow := has_HL_HL_EQ_EQ_EQ_EQ_HL_HL(rightMargin)

if not isSwingLow
    isSwingLow := has_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL_EQ_HL(rightMargin)

// === /CALCULATIONS ===

// === PLOTS ===
plotshape(inputShowSH ? isSwingHigh : na, title='Swing High', style=shape.triangledown, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, text="[SH]", offset=offsetSH, size=size.tiny)
plotshape(inputShowSL ? isSwingLow : na, title='Swing Low', style=shape.triangleup, location=location.belowbar, color=color.green, text="[SL]", offset=offsetSL, size=size.tiny)
// === /PLOTS ===

// === ALERTS ===
alertcondition(isSwingHigh, 'Swing High', 'New Swing High')
alertcondition(isSwingLow, 'Swing Low', 'New Swing Low')
// === /ALERTS ===

график часовой.
нам нужно, чтобы индикатор определял начала и концы импульсных движений, объясню на примере:
берём промежуток в 3 недели. допустим у нас есть дно импульса, потом цена идёт наверх и образует пик нового импульса, потом она идёт ниже дна первого импульса. в таком случае, у нас нисходящий тренд и только после того, как у нас появился тренд (нисходящий или восходящий (для него будет наоборот пример)) на графике индикатор должен отметить точки экстремумов: конец (дно) первого импульса, конец (пик) второго и конец (новое дно) третьего импульса
 'elif' is not a valid type qualifier. Possible values: 'const', 'simple', 'series'

//@version=5
indicator("Multi-Timeframe Candlestick Patterns Strategy for Binary Options", overlay=true)

// Определение таймфреймов
var timeframe4h = "240"
var timeframe1h = "60"
var timeframe15m = "15"
var timeframe5m = "5"

// Функции для определения свечных паттернов
isBullishEngulfing() =>
    (close > open) and (close[1] < open[1]) and (close >= open[1]) and (open <= close[1])

isBearishEngulfing() =>
    (close < open) and (close[1] > open[1]) and (close <= open[1]) and (open >= close[1])

isHammer() =>
    bodySize = abs(close - open)
    lowerShadow = min(open, close) - low
    upperShadow = high - max(open, close)
    (lowerShadow > bodySize * 2) and (upperShadow < bodySize * 0.5)

isHangingMan() =>
    isHammer() and (close < open)

isDoji() =>
    bodySize = abs(close - open)
    bodySize < (high - low) * 0.1

isMorningStar() =>
    firstCandle = close[2] < open[2] and abs(close[2] - open[2]) > abs(high[2] - low[2]) * 0.5
    secondCandle = abs(close[1] - open[1]) < abs(high[1] - low[1]) * 0.3
    thirdCandle = close > open and close > (close[2] + open[2]) / 2
    firstCandle and secondCandle and thirdCandle

isEveningStar() =>
    firstCandle = close[2] > open[2] and abs(close[2] - open[2]) > abs(high[2] - low[2]) * 0.5
    secondCandle = abs(close[1] - open[1]) < abs(high[1] - low[1]) * 0.3
    thirdCandle = close < open and close < (close[2] + open[2]) / 2
    firstCandle and secondCandle and thirdCandle

isThreeWhiteSoldiers() =>
    isBullishCandle1 = close[2] > open[2] and (close[2] - open[2]) > (high[2] - low[2]) * 0.5
    isBullishCandle2 = close[1] > open[1] and (close[1] - open[1]) > (high[1] - low[1]) * 0.5
    isBullishCandle3 = close > open and (close - open) > (high - low) * 0.5
    isBullishCandle1 and isBullishCandle2 and isBullishCandle3

isThreeBlackCrows() =>
    isBearishCandle1 = close[2] < open[2] and (open[2] - close[2]) > (high[2] - low[2]) * 0.5
    isBearishCandle2 = close[1] < open[1] and (open[1] - close[1]) > (high[1] - low[1]) * 0.5
    isBearishCandle3 = close < open and (open - close) > (high - low) * 0.5
    isBearishCandle1 and isBearishCandle2 and isBearishCandle3

isDarkCloudCover() =>
    (close[1] > open[1]) and (open > close[1]) and (close < open) and (close > open[1]) and (close < (open[1] + close[1]) / 2)

isPiercingLine() =>
    (close[1] < open[1]) and (open < close[1]) and (close > open) and (close < open[1]) and (close > (open[1] + close[1]) / 2)

isBullishBeltHold() =>
    (open == low) and (close > open)

isBearishBeltHold() =>
    (open == high) and (close < open)

isBullishHarami() =>
    (close[1] < open[1]) and (open > close) and (close < open) and (open < close[1]) and (close > open[1])

isBearishHarami() =>
    (close[1] > open[1]) and (open < close) and (close > open) and (open > close[1]) and (close < open[1])

// Функция для проверки паттернов на заданном таймфрейме
checkPatterns(tf) =>
    request.security(syminfo.tickerid, tf, )
        isBullishEngulfing() or isBearishEngulfing() or 
        isHammer() or isHangingMan() or 
        isDoji() or isMorningStar() or 
        isEveningStar() or isThreeWhiteSoldiers() or 
        isThreeBlackCrows() or isDarkCloudCover() or 
        isPiercingLine() or isBullishBeltHold() or 
        isBearishBeltHold() or isBullishHarami() or 
        isBearishHarami())

// Проверка всех таймфреймов

sellSignal = checkPatterns(timeframe4h) and checkPatterns(timeframe1h) and checkPatterns(timeframe15m) and checkPatterns(timeframe5m)

// Отображение сигналов на графике

plotshape(series=sellSignal, location=location.abovebar, color=color.red, style=shape.labeldown, text="SELL", size=size.small)// Отображение рекомендованного времени экспирации

# RATING: 800
# TAGS: brute force
# LANGUAGE IS python3
# CORRECT SOLUTION
# In a desperate attempt to obtain your waifu favorite character, you have hacked into the source code of the game. 
# After days of struggling, you finally find the binary string that encodes the gacha system of the game. 
# In order to decode it, you must first solve the following problem.
#
# You are given a binary string s of length n. 
# For each pair of integers (l, r) (1 ≤ l ≤ r ≤ n), count the number of pairs (x, y) (l ≤ x ≤ y ≤ r) such that the amount of 0 equals the amount of 1 in the substring s_x,s_x+1,...,s_y. 
#
# Output the sum of counts over all possible (l, r) modulo 10^9 + 7.
#
# Input 
#
# The first line contains t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) — the number of test cases.
#
# Each test case contains a binary string s (1 ≤ |s| ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5). 
# It is guaranteed s only contains characters 0 and 1.
#
# It is guaranteed the sum of |s| over all test cases does not exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.
#
# Output
#
# For each test case, output an integer, the answer modulo 10^9+7.
#
#
# Example
#
# Input
#
#
# 4
# 0000
# 01010101
# 1100111001
# 11000000111
#
#
# Output
#
#
# 0
# 130
# 147
# 70

# On Penacony, The Land of the Dreams, there exists n houses and n roads. 
# There exists a road between house i and i+1 for all 1 ≤ i ≤ n−1 and a road between house n and house 1. 
# All roads are bidirectional. 
# However, due to the crisis on Penacony, the overseeing family has gone into debt and may not be able to maintain all roads.

# There are m pairs of friendships between the residents of Penacony.

# The first line contains t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10^4) – the number of test cases.
#
# The first line of each test case contains two integers n and m (3 ≤ n ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5, 1 ≤ m ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) – the number of houses and the number of friendships.
#
# The next m lines contain two integers a and b (1 ≤ a < b ≤ n) – the resident in house a is friends with the resident in house b. 
# It is guaranteed all (a, b) are distinct.
#
# It is guaranteed the sum of n and m over all test cases does not exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.
#
# Output
#
# For each test case, output an integer, the minimum number of roads that must be maintained.
#
#
# Example
#

#
#

# 2 7

# 2 12

# 4 10
# 10 2

# 4 1

# RATING: 800
# TAGS: constructive algorithms,math
# LANGUAGE IS python3
# CORRECT SOLUTION
# You are given two strings a and b of length n. 
# Then, you are (forced against your will) to answer q queries.
#
# For each query, you are given a range bounded by l and r. 
# In one operation, you can choose an integer i (l ≤ i ≤ r) and set a_i = x where x is any character you desire. 
# Output the minimum number of operations you must perform such that sorted(a[l..r]) = sorted(b[l..r]). 
# The operations you perform on one query does not affect other queries.
#
# For an arbitrary string c, sorted(c[l..r]) denotes the substring consisting of characters c_l,c_l+1,...,c_r sorted in lexicographical order.
#
# Input 
#
# The first line contains t (1 ≤ t ≤ 1000) – the number of test cases.
#
# The first line of each test case contains two integers n and q (1 ≤ n, q ≤ 2 ⋅ 10^5) – the length of both strings and the number of queries. 
#
# The following line contains a of length n. It is guaranteed a only contains lowercase latin letters.
#
# The following line contains b of length n. It is guaranteed b only contains lowercase latin letters.
#
# The following q lines contain two integers l and r (1 ≤ l ≤ r ≤ n) – the range of the query.
#
# It is guaranteed the sum of n and q over all test cases does not exceed 2 ⋅ 10^5.
#
# Output
#
# For each query, output an integer, the minimum number of operations you need to perform in a new line.
#
# Example
#
# Input
#
#
# 3
# 5 3
# abcde
# edcba
# 1 5
# 1 4
# 3 3
# 4 2
# zzde
# azbe
# 1 3
# 1 4
# 6 3
# uwuwuw
# wuwuwu
# 2 4
# 1 3
# 1 6
#
#
# Output
#
#
# 0
# 1
# 0
# 2
# 2
# 1
# 1
# 0
#
# Note
#
# For the first query, sorted(a[1..5]) = abcde and sorted(b[1..5]) = abcde, so no operations are necessary.
#
# For the second query, you need to set a_1 = e. 
# Then, sorted(a[1..4]) = sorted(b[1..4]) = bcde.
